snippet: A reserve in western Spain is at the forefront of Europe’s “rewilding” effort, which seeks to restore species and ecosystems that vanished centuries ago.
abstract: Campanarios de Azaba Biological Reserve in Spain is at the forefront of ambitious conservation movement that is fast gaining ground in Europe, where vast stretches of farmland are falling into disuse; goal of effort is to take advantage of emptiness to recreate wilderness that once existed on the continent, with possibility of introducing species that have gone extinct.

byline.contributor: Rachel Chaundler contributed reporting from La Alamedilla, and Erik Olsen from Bad Berleburg, Germany.

lead_paragraph: A reserve in western Spain is at the forefront of Europe’s “rewilding” effort, which seeks to restore species and ecosystems that vanished centuries ago.

headline.main: From Untended Farmland, Reserve Tries to Recreate Wilderness From Long Ago
headline.print_headline: From Untended Farmland, Reserve Tries to Recreate Wilderness From Long Ago
